記者真係好慘
多謝，香港有你，小心，保重
強烈譴責 表示極度憤怒

譯左個fb post, 睇下有冇得用來做文宣:

【I was shot 】

At 19:30, I was shot in the head.

I have been on Hong Kong Island all day, shuttling between the eastern and western parts of the island. At night my task was to cover the clearing of the protests. I divided work with my colleagues, hoping that we could cover the events as closely as possible. At 19:30, the protesters were fighting and at the same time retreating. They withdrew from Canal Road Flyover to Hysan Place and Sogo. At the time when this picture was taken, the protesters were taking a rest and organising their equipment.

They retreated further to the Central Library and then Tin Hau.

When riot police charged towards them, the protesters fled eastward. I followed them. Riot police approximately under the Olympic Bridge fired once or twice. They did not fire tear gas. Nor did they give chase. But the stray bullet hit me.

I had been somewhere on the side of the road, not in the middle of it.

I had kept running and looking back. When I was running forward, some buzzing sound approached my ear.

Now I realise that if you are shot in the head, you hear the sound of it a faction of a second beforehand. When the bullet gets very near it causes ringing in the ear.

A dull thump, and a sharp pain in my lower right cheek.

I was shot in the lower right cheek. Part of the head.

I lost my balance. With the help of some first-aiders, I managed to walk for a few steps.

Had I been shot in a higher part of the face, my injury would have been serious.

Had I been shot further back in my face, I would have suffered from more than ringing in the year.

(Whoever shot me) was a remarkable sniper. I was wearing a helmet, goggles and a mask, meaning that better part of my face was protected. I was shot in the lower cheek, the only unprotected bit of my face.

Now I am thinking: had I been shot by live round fired by an assault rifle, I would have heard the same sound before I had been hit. Perhaps I would have felt the same. But my head would have burst.

I wanted to find out what was it that hit me. I was very sure that the projectile moved in a straight line. I was eager to confirm what kind of shooting weapon it was. There were not any protesters behind me.

Very likely it was a sponge-tipped bullet, or a rubber bullet . Called "non-lethal weapons", they are used by the police for clearing protests.

Later I found a rubber bullet on the scene.

It is very dangerous on the scene - and I have not even talked about the abusive phone calls, the crazy torrent of phone calls made from people with different phone numbers who think what they do can hinder my communication with my colleagues and my live broadcast of what is happening - it is getting more dangerous by the week.

A live round has been shot for the first time (on a secondary school boy at Tsuen Wan), and the bullet was fired into his chest already. Things are set on fire as in a manner as carefree as that of a holidaymaker.

In railway stations, police don't even bother to surround those they target - the police hit them right away. The warning flags, black, orange or red, are raised as if they are not.

I was not the only one who was shot.

In such difficult situations, it is more important to stick together and press forward.

Thank you for continuing to care about our home, Hong Kong.

Source: https://www.facebook.com/yuhongchanpage/
